Getting Started

Source: vignettes/gettingstarted.Rmd
gettingstarted.Rmd

Basic usage

Let us consider some messy data.frame as a toy example:

library(linelist)
ll_sample <- messy_data()

We can use clean_data() with defaults to let the package to do its best to clean up the data.

clean_data(ll_sample)
#>        id date_of_onset  discharge gender epi_case_definition       messy_dates
#> 1  atgebw    2018-01-09 19_01_2018 female          not_a_case that_s_24_12_1989
#> 2  ymtidn    2018-01-11 21_01_2018 female           confirmed              male
#> 3  hbfwiz    2018-01-04 14_01_2018   male           suspected        2018_10_19
#> 4  fcskvg    2018-01-04 14_01_2018 female            probable        2018_10_18
#> 5  nwveqa    2018-01-06 16_01_2018 female          not_a_case        2018_10_17
#> 6  dlesii    2018-01-11 21_01_2018 female           confirmed            female
#> 7  rzfvgj    2018-01-04 14_01_2018   male           suspected        2018_10_19
#> 8  ivczpb    2018-01-11 21_01_2018   male           confirmed        01_12_2001
#> 9  indisl    2018-01-02 12_01_2018   male            probable              <NA>
#> 10 assxcj    2018-01-06 16_01_2018 female          not_a_case        01_12_2001
#> 11 dmesnm    2018-01-08 18_01_2018   male           suspected        2018_10_18
#> 12 wloxbp    2018-01-05 15_01_2018 female           confirmed that_s_24_12_1989
#> 13 nbyaen    2018-01-05 15_01_2018 female           confirmed        01_12_2001
#> 14 qwfybm    2018-01-05 15_01_2018 female           suspected              <NA>
#> 15 hcssgt    2018-01-09 19_01_2018   male            probable        24_12_1989
#> 16 cmsxei    2018-01-05 15_01_2018 female            probable that_s_24_12_1989
#> 17 rsiopf    2018-01-03 13_01_2018 female          not_a_case              male
#> 18 fkuxxu    2018-01-02 12_01_2018 female          not_a_case        01_12_2001
#> 19 ihexio    2018-01-08 18_01_2018   male          not_a_case              male
#> 20 rqtzrq    2018-01-06 16_01_2018 female            probable        24_12_1989
#>         lat      lon
#> 1  10.94005 49.40389
#> 2  12.72885 48.24777

#> 20 15.21307 48.25225

Intermediate use

The clean_data() function comes with switches for many of the cleaning capabilities so that you can define a bespoke cleaning process.

clean_data(ll_sample, guess_dates = TRUE, error_tolerance = 0.1)
#>        id date_of_onset  discharge gender epi_case_definition       messy_dates
#> 1  atgebw    2018-01-09 2018-01-19 female          not_a_case that_s_24_12_1989
#> 2  ymtidn    2018-01-11 2018-01-21 female           confirmed              male
#> 3  hbfwiz    2018-01-04 2018-01-14   male           suspected        2018_10_19
#> 4  fcskvg    2018-01-04 2018-01-14 female            probable        2018_10_18
#> 5  nwveqa    2018-01-06 2018-01-16 female          not_a_case        2018_10_17
#> 6  dlesii    2018-01-11 2018-01-21 female           confirmed            female
#> 7  rzfvgj    2018-01-04 2018-01-14   male           suspected        2018_10_19
#> 8  ivczpb    2018-01-11 2018-01-21   male           confirmed        01_12_2001
#> 9  indisl    2018-01-02 2018-01-12   male            probable              <NA>
#> 10 assxcj    2018-01-06 2018-01-16 female          not_a_case        01_12_2001
#> 11 dmesnm    2018-01-08 2018-01-18   male           suspected        2018_10_18
#> 12 wloxbp    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female           confirmed that_s_24_12_1989
#> 13 nbyaen    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female           confirmed        01_12_2001
#> 14 qwfybm    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female           suspected              <NA>
#> 15 hcssgt    2018-01-09 2018-01-19   male            probable        24_12_1989
#> 16 cmsxei    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female            probable that_s_24_12_1989
#> 17 rsiopf    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female          not_a_case              male
#> 18 fkuxxu    2018-01-02 2018-01-12 female          not_a_case        01_12_2001
#> 19 ihexio    2018-01-08 2018-01-18   male          not_a_case              male
#> 20 rqtzrq    2018-01-06 2018-01-16 female            probable        24_12_1989
#>         lat      lon
#> 1  10.94005 49.40389
#> 2  12.72885 48.24777
#> 3  13.93884 48.09218
#> 4  12.49403 47.07289
#> 5  12.88882 47.65609
#> 6  11.59685 48.88115
#> 7  15.10612 47.11574
#> 8  12.12622 48.63946
#> 9  12.97682 48.36241
#> 10 14.21873 47.98829
#> 11 15.28026 47.84267
#> 12 11.98698 45.61135
#> 13 14.69749 46.90592
#> 14 10.82026 46.77039
#> 15 14.60055 50.52635
#> 16 11.72615 46.31837
#> 17 13.77469 48.17686
#> 18 10.96579 48.63244
#> 19 16.38651 48.39418
#> 20 15.21307 48.25225

We can prevent the cleaning process from operating on certain columns.

clean_data(ll_sample, guess_dates = TRUE, protect = names(ll_sample) == "messy/dates")
#>        id date_of_onset  discharge gender epi_case_definition
#> 1  atgebw    2018-01-09 2018-01-19 female          not_a_case
#> 2  ymtidn    2018-01-11 2018-01-21 female           confirmed
#> 3  hbfwiz    2018-01-04 2018-01-14   male           suspected
#> 4  fcskvg    2018-01-04 2018-01-14 female            probable
#> 5  nwveqa    2018-01-06 2018-01-16 female          not_a_case
#> 6  dlesii    2018-01-11 2018-01-21 female           confirmed
#> 7  rzfvgj    2018-01-04 2018-01-14   male           suspected
#> 8  ivczpb    2018-01-11 2018-01-21   male           confirmed
#> 9  indisl    2018-01-02 2018-01-12   male            probable
#> 10 assxcj    2018-01-06 2018-01-16 female          not_a_case
#> 11 dmesnm    2018-01-08 2018-01-18   male           suspected
#> 12 wloxbp    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female           confirmed
#> 13 nbyaen    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female           confirmed
#> 14 qwfybm    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female           suspected
#> 15 hcssgt    2018-01-09 2018-01-19   male            probable
#> 16 cmsxei    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female            probable
#> 17 rsiopf    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female          not_a_case
#> 18 fkuxxu    2018-01-02 2018-01-12 female          not_a_case
#> 19 ihexio    2018-01-08 2018-01-18   male          not_a_case
#> 20 rqtzrq    2018-01-06 2018-01-16 female            probable
#>           messy/dates      lat      lon
#> 1  that's 24/12/1989! 10.94005 49.40389
#> 2                male 12.72885 48.24777
#> 3          2018 10 19 13.93884 48.09218
#> 4          2018-10-18 12.49403 47.07289
#> 5          2018_10_17 12.88882 47.65609
#> 6              female 11.59685 48.88115
#> 7          2018 10 19 15.10612 47.11574
#> 8          01-12-2001 12.12622 48.63946
#> 9                <NA> 12.97682 48.36241
#> 10         01-12-2001 14.21873 47.98829
#> 11         2018-10-18 15.28026 47.84267
#> 12 that's 24/12/1989! 11.98698 45.61135
#> 13         01-12-2001 14.69749 46.90592
#> 14               <NA> 10.82026 46.77039
#> 15    // 24//12//1989 14.60055 50.52635
#> 16 that's 24/12/1989! 11.72615 46.31837
#> 17               male 13.77469 48.17686
#> 18         01-12-2001 10.96579 48.63244
#> 19               male 16.38651 48.39418
#> 20    // 24//12//1989 15.21307 48.25225

If we have values that are multi-lingual or possibly have typos, we can generate a wordlist that contains two columns, from and to, that will be used to transform any found values in specified columns.

wordlist <- data.frame(
 from  = c("hopsital", "hopital",  "medical", "feild"),
 to    = c("hospital", "hospital", "clinic",  "field"),
 variables = rep("location", 4),
 stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

# location data with mis-spellings, French, and English.
messy_locations <- c("hopsital", "h\u00f4pital", "hospital",
                     "m\u00e9dical", "clinic",
                     "feild", "field")
llsample_spell <- messy_data()
llsample_spell$location <- factor(sample(messy_locations, 20, replace = TRUE))

clean_data(llsample_spell, wordlists = wordlist, spelling_vars = "variables" )
#>        id date_of_onset  discharge gender epi_case_definition messy_dates
#> 1  fkoynq    2018-01-11 21_01_2018   male          not_a_case      female
#> 2  ljifcq    2018-01-11 21_01_2018   male           confirmed  2018_10_19
#> 3  vacydl    2018-01-07 17_01_2018   male           confirmed      female
#> 4  ojeoma    2018-01-07 17_01_2018   male            probable        <NA>
#> 5  qaocfr    2018-01-05 15_01_2018 female            probable  2018_10_17
#> 6  xvstqe    2018-01-02 12_01_2018 female          not_a_case        <NA>
#> 7  owndqd    2018-01-03 13_01_2018 female           confirmed  2018_10_17
#> 8  bnszcm    2018-01-06 16_01_2018   male           confirmed  2018_10_19
#> 9  ttvrgl    2018-01-06 16_01_2018 female           suspected  01_12_2001
#> 10 cwapvi    2018-01-03 13_01_2018   male          not_a_case  24_12_1989
#> 11 xhlhfh    2018-01-09 19_01_2018   male          not_a_case  01_12_2001

#> 16 lkjbzi    2018-01-10 20_01_2018   male            probable        <NA>
#> 17 muhayh    2018-01-08 18_01_2018   male           suspected  2018_10_17

Advanced usage

As well as the configurable clean_data() function, many of the capabilities are exposed individually, supporting data pipelines.

llsample_pipe <- ll_sample
llsample_pipe <- clean_dates(llsample_pipe)
llsample_pipe <- clean_variable_names(llsample_pipe)

This gives you highly granular control over the process and is advised when building functions for processing data in your specific usecase / environment.

You can then see the impact of changes by comparing two linelist data.frames.

compare_data(ll_sample, llsample_pipe)
#> 
#>  /// Comparisons of data content // 
#>      (showing differences only)
#> 
#> 
#>  // Comparison of dimensions /
#> Same number of rows and columns
#> 
#>  // Comparison of variable names /
#> 
#>   * variables missing in the new data:
#> [1] "'ID"                 "Date of Onset."      "DisCharge.."        
#> [4] "GENDER_ "            "Épi.Case_définition" "messy/dates"        
#> 
#>   * new variables:
#> [1] "id"                  "date_of_onset"       "discharge"          
#> [4] "gender"              "epi_case_definition" "messy_dates"        
#> 
#> 
#>  // Comparison of variable classes /
#> 
#> 
#>  // Comparison of values in categorical variables /
